This has stood out to me very clearly as I've had the chance to start teaching others to code. I started teaching my little brother to code a couple of years ago, and at first he would put all variables in the global scope. No arguments, no local variables, no return values -- everything just lives at the top-level, and if you want to change something you do!
This worked perfectly well as long as your code stayed within about 75 lines, which it did for a while! There's a lot you can learn without making programs longer than 75 lines.

But then as the programs he made started to get longer, he would experience the maintenance cost of this approach -- having to add a lot of variables, and search through the code to find & replace when he wanted to change even small things.
And so we shifted over to using function arguments, return values and local variables.

I think we've all had this experience when learning programming, that the way you code at the start, while easier when you're learning, ends up being a nightmare to debug. And so you adopt different practices that result in more maintainable code.
easy to learn vs easy to maintain (syntax / language features version maybe)
One place we're hoping to be better than javascript is that you won't have boilerplate, you won't have to pick from a ton of different options, we'll just bake something in that will work.

From facebook's perspective, you can imagine they've got a lot of javascript, and they're coming up against a lot of limitations -- with so many people & so much javascript, the maintenance burden is immense, lots of bugs, etc. So they try to make things better with flow, a gradual type system that you can add onto your existing javascript. But even then you're stuck with existing javascript runtime semantics, and the type system has to be made fairly permissive in order to not get in the way of existing javascript idioms.
So they have experience with this other language, OCaml, that has a ton of desirable properties, but they need to tweak a bunch of things so that the adoption curve isn't so steep.

Jared Forsyth
[[kalogo]] Khan Academy
Hi! I'm Jared, and I do mobile, react-native, and web development at Khan Academy, where we're working to create a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.
Reason:

!a "We want people to be able to use powerful, well-typed languages at work, not just in their free time"

- Jordan Walke
help more people have more fun programming, at work, not just on the side

It's one thing to have the fun, new programming language be something you talk about at meetups & use for side projects. But it's a whole nother step if you can start using it at your day job. /And as we work to bring functional, well-typed programming to more and more people, we're doing so in tandum with other languages as well, like Elm and PureScript. We're all working to grow the functional programming pie.
In order to deliver on this goal, I'm going to focus on 2 {{areas we want to optimize}} | {{things we need to do well}} | {{things Reason needs to be good at}}: Adoption & Maintenance
Why Reason?
adoption
!h easy to start
maintenance
!h easy to keep going
_ adoption & maintenance
~~adoption~~
easy to start
~~maintenance~~
easy to keep going
We want to make it as easy as we can to get started with this language, *without* sacrificing maintainability down the line.
*caveat, easy(er) than current solutions. Software will always be hard, but we're trying to tackle some of the problems we see with existing systems.

one thing that impressed me about angular, when it was first getting popular, is how easy it was to get started. You add a script tag to your html page, add an attribute to your body tag, and you're up and running! So much less work to get a simple form going than backbone & friends.

What happened though, was that once I worked for a while with angular on a large production app with a bunch of other people, is the maintenance burden became enormous! What was easy to start with didn't end up having the structure and patterns to make it easy to keep going.
This was in 2014, and so when React came out it was fantastic to have the structure & patterns of state management and componentization, which made larger applications so much easier to maintain.
But then React paid a cost in adoption -- to get anywhere you had to learn about JSX, and you had to setup this transpiler webpack plugin, etc.

And in the years since then we've seen an explosion of javascript tools & configurations, boilerplates and setup-kits, in the majority of cases aimed at attacking the second problem -- scaling large apps, making it easy to maintain. And so we got flux, redux, babel, etc.
But then of course there was the backlash: javascript fatigue. We had dialed up so much on the "we want things that scale to large apps & teams" that we harmed the initial experience.
oh insert tweet from @JavascriptDev or whatever the napolean dynamite thing is talking about "we set up babel"
And finally after lots of back & forth & fatigue, we got create-react-app, which tries to make it once again easy to start.
Because these two things can sometimes be in conflict!
_ easy to start, easy to keep going, angular story

!a ![adoption_vs_maintenance.png]()
I'm putting JavaScript as the baseline here -- its adoption is tremendous, and if you've worked on large javascript apps you probably have some idea of places it can be hard to maintain.
We didn't get arrow functions & const & let b/c it was a barrier to beginners.
People started up just fine without that, and adding new features to the language means that many more things to learn!
But having const & arrow functions sure made your maintenance job easier when you were working on a large app, with many people, over the course of many months.
So we won some maintainability, at the cost of some complexity & ease of adoption
Now I'm splitting out es6+ because I think there's an interesting story here.
I'll caveat that this graph is a rather poor representation of reality -- in fact, there are a ton of dimensions, and something can help maintainability & hurt it in different ways.
So that was just within one language! How do things compare between languages? {{TODO look for evan's talk + chart.}}

Ok so let's dig into adoption and maintenance -- aspects of the reason project that are aimed at making both of these vectors great. And as I talk about various parts of this ecosystem, I'm going to include a 3-star rating system to indicate to you how far along we are. Reason is in some ways still starting out, and while we've got a lot to offer, it's still a work-in-progress.
Along the way, I'll try to give caveats about "how far along we are" to delivering on these various goals --- some we've got pretty well solid, and some are quite aspiration at this point.
_ 3-star readiness system

I'm going to start things off with the adoption bit, because I want y'all to know what it would be like to start using Reason. Then I'll talk about all the long-term benefits that you'll also be buying into when you jump on this train.

Reason's syntactic evolution
I've heard people say that it's easier than learning a new language, because so many things are familiar. This is the absolute jackpot.
elm & clojure --- don't think it's a big deal, but in my experience it sure adds to the barrier. In clojure's case I can buy it b/c homeoiconicity is rad.
we've had a fair amount of skepticism -- especially from those who already know & love OCaml -- but some have come back saying "yeah this was a good thing".
quote by chenglou

I'm extremely proud of our community here, being understanding enough that we're making decisions that are personally a negative for ourselves but positive for the potential folks we'll be welcoming. The whole point of the syntax part of the Reason project isn't for us to convince our bosses; I'd say I'm doing a fine job of that already by myself. The point is for others to convince their bosses without getting blocked on trivialities (that turned out not so trivial after all) like syntax and pretty css on docs @chenglou
What are thie points I want to make?

As we've been evolving reason's syntax & bringing it closer to javascript, we've had several people come into the chatroom who "liked the old way better". And it's funny b/c the argument frequently sounds like "why are you changing it, I like the old way better, and also syntax doesn't even matter shouldn't you be spending time on more important things?

Syntax is a funny thing. If you're drenched in it, it can feel like the simplest thing in the world. If you're more used to something quite different, it can trip you up rather consistently. I've had more than a few annoying syntax errors when switching between javascript, python and clojurescript!
Now you might say "lol syntax errors are the absolute least of our worries" but in my experience it's an annoyance that I'd love to be rid of -- get rid of things that interriupt flow

While there might be variations in the effectiveness of various syntaxes in how well they can be read/understood etc. people frequently express the opinion that "it's the smallest deal why are we even talking about it."
But I can say from experience that gosh it turns out to be a big deal at deterring people who want to investigate!

Rich Hickey said in his keynote at Clojure Conj a few weeks ago (Oct 12) that "the parens thing is a non-issue", and cites the success of clojure as evidence: Look at how many people there are for whom it was a non-issue, or who overcame it without giving up! I call proof-by-example and say it's unsatisfying. I for one took longer to take up clojure because the syntax was so different from what I was used to (although homeoiconicity is neat), and the fact that haskell's and elm's syntaxes are so different has been a pretty big deterrant for me from getting started there too! Also OCaml's syntax, my goodness. Although I eventually braved those waters to the point where I can reasonably write OCaml (btw I do think it's objectively worse).
And I've talked to several people who say that having the syntax be closer to javascript is a nice thing, makes it an easier sell for them & their collegues.

One argument I've heard is "they're different, we don't want people getting mixed up!" Well Java & C++ have quite similar syntaxes, are we super worried about people getting confused about the differences between those languages?

Also to the people who say "it's not even a big deal get over it", if we want to make the syntax like javascript, isn't that not a big deal? So in sum: those who don't think syntax is a big deal -- you shouldn't have a problem w/ us changing the syntax! And for those coming from JS for whom a familiar syntax will make it that much easier -- we're doing this for you.

So we're making the syntax quite close to javascript. in some trivial cases it's indistinguishable! (weird idea: what if you had a babel syntax plugin that parsed reason? or something weird like that.)

I'd like to chime in and say that even though I prefer ML syntax, as someone who works in a JS environment with a dozen JS devs, the decision to go JS-like syntax is the right one. I've had my coworkers, who are interested in FP, look at my reason code as well as examples from y'all, and the ML syntax does seem like a hurdle for adoption. Telling them that it's changing to be more JS-like put their minds at ease, and it made it far easier to show them how cool the typesystem is and the sort of things  you can do with it. 

We have bi-weekly programming workshops at my job, and I was going to do a Reason demo once the syntax changes. I'm confident a familiar syntax will allow them to see the advantages as opposed to getting hung up on that one detail. And I guarantee they would get hung up on it, haha. People say don't judge a book by its cover (syntax), but that's totally what people do, at least initially. Reason with a JS-like syntax has the potential to blow all the major competition out of the water. Y'all are gunna end up killing Typescript and Flow (never particularly liked either of them, so I'm fine with that).
Oh and I was totally one of those people who came barging into this community demanding the syntax be left alone :joy: Y'all won me over

It hurts me to say that something so shallow as requiring a few extra spaces can have a bigger effect than, say, Hindley-Milner type inference. I wish it weren't so, but that is what my classroom experience tells me, loudly and unambiguously
http://okasaki.blogspot.com/2008/02/in-praise-of-mandatory-indentation-for.html

Definitely. Especially since currently knowing JS pretty much guarantees you a job, so you really have to convince them to jump on a different tech stack. I know when I present this language I'm gunna get a "well why the hell would I use this when I'm getting by in JS??" I had to have that conversation when I presented React... a month ago, so it wasn't even new. People can easily get stuck in their ways, so having one less sticking point is definitely benificial

ClojureScript: 2nd-class -- ecosystem isn't that well helped, but actually interacting w/ js isn't a big deal
Elm: 3rd-class -- keep js at arm's length to preserve safety
Reason: 1st-class -- we're on npm, and interop w/ js is rediculously easy
hmmm maybe these class rankings are the wrong tack. might want another graphic
Calling javascript from clojurescript is not that hard, but the ecosystem is based on maven & java's stack, not on npm. So there's some more barrier there

Elm is way cool because they emphasize safety much more. (for example, no runtime exceptions on the language). They keep elm at arm's length, in order to preserve runtime safety. So the only (blessed) way to communicate with javascript is through structured ports that make sure you're not letting any poorly-typed data into your system. Their packaging ecosystem is like hackage maybe? prolly not. But they've got their own deal, and it like pretty well discourages fraternizing with unsafe javascript.

Flow & TypeScript, for comparison, are about as close to the metal as you can get. In flow's case, there's no runtime difference, and you can gradually add types to an existing codebase. With TypeScript, there's barely any runtime difference, and adoption is similarly well-supported.
With Reason, we're compromising some privacy for safety :P
we're trading some safety for ease of adoption.
I'm including ClojureScript on here because it's way cool, and I think it's an interesting point of comparison.

and always at the boundary you'll have type definitions that need to stay in sync but probably don't always. It requires manual curation and you make mistakes, and even if you don't it's annoying.

with a server written in reason compiled to native, and the client written in reason compiled to javascript, you can have performant, idiomatic code for both client & server, and they *share type definitions*. You can have it so that if your code type checks, all of your REST endpoints & API calls are well-typed.
And if you bring graphql into the picture, then you can really have some fun.
